greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is number of partitions of n that have k parts smaller than the largest part (n>=1, k>=0).
comment: Also number of partitions of n such that the difference between the largest and smallest parts is k (see A097364). Example: T(6,2)=3 because we have [4,2],[3,2,1] and [3,1,1,1].
Row 1 has one term; row n (n>=2) has n-1 terms.
Row sums yield the partition numbers (A000041).
T(n,1)=A049820(n) (n minus number of divisors of n).
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..142, flattened
G. E. Andrews, M. Beck and N. Robbins, Partitions with fixed differences between largest and smallest parts, arXiv:1406.3374 [math.NT], 2014.
maple: g:=sum(x^i/(1-x^i)/product(1-t*x^j,j=1..i-1),i=1..50): gser:=simplify(series(g,x=0,18)): for n from 1 to 15 do P[n]:=coeff(gser,x^n) od: 1; for n from 2 to 15 do seq(coeff(P[n],t,j),j=0..n-2) od;
mathematica: rows = 15; max = rows + 2; col[k0_ /; k0 > 0] := col[k0] = Sum[x^(2*k + k0)/Product[ (1 - x^(k + j)), {j, 0, k0}], {k, 1, Ceiling[max/2]}] + O[x]^max // CoefficientList[#, x] &; col[0] := Table[Switch[n, 1, 0, 2, 1, _, n - 1 - col[1][[n]]], {n, 1, Length[col[1]]}]; Join[{1}, Table[ col[k][[n+2]], {n, 0, rows-1}, {k, 0, n-1}] // Flatten] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Sep 11 2017, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 23 2006
